sn7.11:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle.
sn7.11:1.3.en: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.

sn7.11:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa kammanto tenupasaṅkami.
sn7.11:1.4.en: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.

sn7.11:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa parivesanā vattati.
sn7.11:2.1.en: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.

sn7.11:2.3.pli: Addasā kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ piṇḍāya ṭhitaṁ.
sn7.11:2.3.en: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms

sn7.11:2.10.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.11:2.10.en: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn7.11:3.3.en: If you’re a farmer, declare to me:

sn7.11:11.1.pli: Evaṁ vutte, kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
sn7.11:11.1.en: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer said to the Buddha,

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 7
2. Lay Followers
11. With Bhāradvāja the Farmer

an3.92:1.1.en: “Mendicants, a farmer has three urgent duties.

an3.92:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kassako gahapati sīghaṁ sīghaṁ khettaṁ sukaṭṭhaṁ karoti sumatikataṁ.
an3.92:1.3.en: A farmer swiftly makes sure the field is well ploughed and tilled.

an3.92:1.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi kassakassa gahapatissa accāyikāni karaṇīyāni.
an3.92:1.6.en: These are the three urgent duties of a farmer.

an3.92:1.7.pli: Tassa kho taṁ, bhikkhave, kassakassa gahapatissa natthi sā iddhi vā ānubhāvo vā:
an3.92:1.7.en: That farmer has no special power or ability to say:

an3.92:1.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṁ tassa kassakassa gahapatissa tāni dhaññāni utupariṇāmīni jāyantipi gabbhīnipi honti paccantipi.
an3.92:1.9.en: But there comes a time when that farmer’s crops germinate, flower, and ripen as the seasons change.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 3
10. A Lump of Salt
92. Urgent

dn23:31.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṁ ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya.
dn23:31.2.en: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.

dn23:31.5.pli: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyyuṁ, kassako vā vipulaṁ phalaṁ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
dn23:31.5.en: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”

dn23:31.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṁ ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya.
dn23:31.9.en: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.

dn23:31.12.pli: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyyuṁ, kassako vā vipulaṁ phalaṁ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
dn23:31.12.en: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”

an3.83:1.1.en: “Mendicants, a farmer has three primary duties.

an3.83:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kassako gahapati paṭikacceva khettaṁ sukaṭṭhaṁ karoti sumatikataṁ.
an3.83:1.3.en: A farmer first of all makes sure the field is well ploughed and tilled.

an3.83:1.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi kassakassa gahapatissa pubbe karaṇīyāni.
an3.83:1.6.en: These are the three primary duties of a farmer.

dn2:37.5.pli: idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
dn2:37.5.en: Suppose you had a person who was a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.

dn2:37.10.pli: Ahaṁ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
dn2:37.10.en: Whereas I’m a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.

dn2:37.20.pli: ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako’”ti?
dn2:37.20.en: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital’?”

sn7.12:2.3.en: again and again, farmers plough the field;

sn7.12:4.1.en: Again and again, dairy farmers milk;

sn4.19:2.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā kassakavaṇṇaṁ abhinimminitvā mahantaṁ naṅgalaṁ khandhe karitvā dīghapācanayaṭṭhiṁ gahetvā haṭahaṭakeso sāṇasāṭinivattho kaddamamakkhitehi pādehi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
sn4.19:2.4.en: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of a farmer carrying a large plough on his shoulder. He held a long goad, his hair was messy, he was clad in sunn hemp, and his feet were muddy. He went up to the Buddha and said to him,

an3.93:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kassakassa gahapatissa sampannaṁ sālikkhettaṁ.
an3.93:6.1.en: When a farmer’s rice field is ripe,

an3.93:6.13.pli: Evamassu tāni, bhikkhave, kassakassa gahapatissa dhaññāni aggappattāni sārappattāni suddhāni sāre patiṭṭhitāni.
an3.93:6.13.en: In this way that farmer’s crop would reach the peak and the pith, being pure and consisting only of what is essential.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 3
10. A Lump of Salt
93. Seclusion

sn42.7:1.7.pli: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, gāmaṇi, idhassu kassakassa gahapatino tīṇi khettāni—ekaṁ khettaṁ aggaṁ, ekaṁ khettaṁ majjhimaṁ, ekaṁ khettaṁ hīnaṁ jaṅgalaṁ ūsaraṁ pāpabhūmi.
sn42.7:1.7.en: What do you think? Suppose a farmer has three fields: one’s good, one’s average, and one’s poor—bad ground of sand and salt.

sn42.7:1.8.pli: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, gāmaṇi, asu kassako gahapati bījāni patiṭṭhāpetukāmo kattha paṭhamaṁ patiṭṭhāpeyya, yaṁ vā aduṁ khettaṁ aggaṁ, yaṁ vā aduṁ khettaṁ majjhimaṁ, yaṁ vā aduṁ khettaṁ hīnaṁ jaṅgalaṁ ūsaraṁ pāpabhūmī”ti?
sn42.7:1.8.en: What do you think? When that farmer wants to plant seeds, where would he plant them first: the good field, the average one, or the poor one?”

mn50:10.3.pli: Addasaṁsu kho, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino āyasmantaṁ sañjīvaṁ aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ samāpannaṁ nisinnaṁ;
mn50:10.3.en: Some cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him sitting there

mn50:11.2.pli: Addasaṁsu kho te, pāpima, gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino āyasmantaṁ sañjīvaṁ piṇḍāya carantaṁ;
mn50:11.2.en: Those cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him wandering for alms

mn98:10.4.en: as a farmer, not a brahmin.

mn98:12.13.en: You’re a farmer by your deeds,

dn16:4.30.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā avidūre bhusāgārassa dve kassakā bhātaro hatā cattāro ca balibaddā.
dn16:4.30.2.en: At that time it was raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking. And not far from the threshing-hut two farmers who were brothers were killed, as well as four oxen.

dn16:4.32.2.pli: ‘Idāni, bhante, deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā dve kassakā bhātaro hatā cattāro ca balibaddā.
dn16:4.32.2.en: ‘Just now, sir, it was raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking. And two farmers who were brothers were killed, as well as four oxen.

sn22.102:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, saradasamaye kassako mahānaṅgalena kasanto sabbāni mūlasantānakāni sampadālento kasati;
sn22.102:2.1.en: In the autumn, a farmer ploughing with a large plough shears through all the root networks.

mn86:3.3.pli: Addasāsuṁ kho gopālakā pasupālakā kassakā pathāvino bhagavantaṁ yena coro aṅgulimālo tenaddhānamaggapaṭipannaṁ.
mn86:3.3.en: The cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and travelers saw him on the road,
